#average.summary:
Calculate the average value of an array. Returns undefined if some elements
are not numbers.

returns.description: The average (arithmetic mean) of the list of numbers.

#compact.summary: Returns a copy of the array without null and undefined values.

returns.description: A new array that contains only the non-null values.

#copy.summary:
Creates and returns a copy of the array. The copy contains
the same objects.
#copy.code_sample:
a = ["a", "b", "c"]
b = a.copy()

# their elements are equal
a[0] == b[0] && a[1] == b[1] && a[2] == b[2]
# => true

# but they aren't the same object in memory
a === b
# => false

returns.description: A new array that is a copy of the array

#clear.summary: Empties the array of its contents. It is modified in place.

returns.description: this, now emptied.

#flatten.summary: Flatten out an array of arrays into a single array of elements.
#flatten.code_sample:
[[1, 2], [3, 4], 5].flatten()
# => [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

# won't flatten twice nested arrays. call
# flatten twice if that is what you want
[[1, 2], [3, [4, 5]], 6].flatten()
# => [1, 2, 3, [4, 5], 6]

returns.description: A new array with all the sub-arrays flattened to the top.

#invoke.summary:
Invoke the named method on each element in the array
and return a new array containing the results of the invocation.

method.description: The name of the method to invoke.

Optional.description: arguments to pass to the method being invoked.

returns.description: A new array containing the results of invoking the named method on each element.

#rand.summary: Randomly select an element from the array.

returns.description: A random element from an array

#remove.summary:
Remove the first occurrence of the given object from the array if it is
present. The array is modified in place.

object.description: The object to remove from the array if present.

returns.description: The removed object if present otherwise undefined.

#include.summary: Returns true if the element is present in the array.

element.description: The element to check if present.

returns.description: true if the element is in the array, false otherwise.

#each.summary:
Call the given iterator once for each element in the array,
passing in the element as the first argument, the index of
the element as the second argument, and this array as the
third argument.
#each.code_sample:
word = ""
indices = []
["r", "a", "d"].each (letter, index) ->
  word += letter
  indices.push(index)

# => ["r", "a", "d"]

word
# => "rad"

indices
# => [0, 1, 2]

iterator.description: Function to be called once for each element in the array.

context.description: Optional context parameter to be used as `this` when calling the iterator function.

returns.description: this to enable method chaining.

#map.summary:
Creates a new array with the results of calling a provided function on every
element in this array.

Function.description: that produces an element of the new Array

#eachPair.summary: Call the given iterator once for each pair of objects in the array.

iterator.description: Function to be called once for each pair of elements in the array.

context.description: Optional context parameter to be used as `this` when calling the iterator function.

#eachWithObject.summary:
Call the given iterator once for each element in the array,
passing in the element as the first argument and the given object
as the second argument. Additional arguments are passed similar to
each.

object.description: The object to pass to the iterator on each visit.

iterator.description: Function to be called once for each element in the array.

context.description: Optional context parameter to be used as `this` when calling the iterator function.

returns.description: this

#eachSlice.summary:
Call the given iterator once for each group of elements in the array,
passing in the elements in groups of n. Additional argumens are
passed as in each.

n.description: The number of elements in each group.

iterator.description: Function to be called once for each group of elements in the array.

context.description: Optional context parameter to be used as `this` when calling the iterator function.

returns.description: this

#pipeline.summary:
Pipe the input through each function in the array in turn. For example, if you have a
list of objects you can perform a series of selection, sorting, and other processing
methods and then receive the processed list. This array must contain functions that
accept a single input and return the processed input. The output of the first function
is fed to the input of the second and so on until the final processed output is returned.

input.description: The initial input to pass to the first function in the pipeline.

returns.description: The result of processing the input by each function in the array.

#shuffle.summary: Returns a new array with the elements all shuffled up.

returns.description: A new array that is randomly shuffled.

#first.summary: Returns the first element of the array, undefined if the array is empty.

returns.description: The first element, or undefined if the array is empty.

#last.summary: Returns the last element of the array, undefined if the array is empty.

returns.description: The last element, or undefined if the array is empty.

#extremes.summary: Returns an object containing the extremes of this array.

fn.description: An optional funtion used to evaluate each element to calculate its value for determining extremes.

returns.description: {min: minElement, max: maxElement}

#wrap.summary:
Pretend the array is a circle and grab a new array containing length elements.
If length is not given return the element at start, again assuming the array
is a circle.

start.description: The index to start wrapping at, or the index of the sole element to return if no length is given.

length.description: Optional length determines how long result array should be.

returns.description: or {Array} The element at start mod array.length, or an array of length elements, starting from start and wrapping.

#partition.summary:
Partitions the elements into two groups: those for which the iterator returns
true, and those for which it returns false.

context.description: Optional context parameter to be used as `this` when calling the iterator function.

returns.description: An array in the form of [trueCollection, falseCollection]

#select.summary: Return the group of elements for which the return value of the iterator is true.

iterator.description: The iterator receives each element in turn as the first agument.

context.description: Optional context parameter to be used as `this` when calling the iterator function.

returns.description: An array containing the elements for which the iterator returned true.

#without.summary: Return the group of elements that are not in the passed in set.

returns.description: An array containing the elements that are not passed in.

#reject.summary: Return the group of elements for which the return value of the iterator is false.

iterator.description: The iterator receives each element in turn as the first agument.

context.description: Optional context parameter to be used as `this` when calling the iterator function.

returns.description: An array containing the elements for which the iterator returned false.

#inject.summary:
Combines all elements of the array by applying a binary operation.
for each element in the arra the iterator is passed an accumulator
value (memo) and the element.

returns.description: The result of a

#sum.summary: Add all the elements in the array.

returns.description: The sum of the elements in the array.

#product.summary: Multiply all the elements in the array.

returns.description: The product of the elements in the array.

#zip.summary: Merges together the values of each of the arrays with the values at the corresponding position.

returns.description: Array groupings whose values are arranged by their positions in the original input arrays.

#pop.summary: Removes the last element from an array and returns that element.

#push.summary:
Mutates an array by appending the given elements and returning the new length of
the array.

...,.description: elementN The elements to add to the end of the array.

#reverse.summary:
Reverses an array in place. The first array element becomes the last and the
last becomes the first.

#shift.summary:
Removes the first element from an array and returns that element. This method
changes the length of the array.

#sort.summary: Sorts the elements of an array in place.

Specifies.description: a function that defines the sort order. If

Changes the content of an array, adding new elements while removing old
elements.

An.description: integer indicating the number of old array elements to

...,.description: elementN The elements to add to the array. If you don't

#unshift.summary:
Adds one or more elements to the beginning of an array and returns the new
length of the array.

...,.description: elementN The elements to add to the front of the array.

#concat.summary:
Returns a new array comprised of this array joined with other array(s) and/or
value(s).

Arrays.description: and/or values to concatenate to the resulting array.

#join.summary: Joins all elements of an array into a string.

Specifies.description: a string to separate each element of the array. The

#slice.summary: Returns a one-level deep copy of a portion of an array.

Zero-based.description: index at which to end extraction. slice extracts up to

#toString.summary: Returns a string representing the specified array and its elements.

#indexOf.summary:
Returns the first index at which a given element can be found in the array, or
-1 if it is not present.

fromIndex.description: Element to locate in the array.The index at

#lastIndexOf.summary:
Returns the last index at which a given element can be found in the array, or -1
if it is not present. The array is searched backwards, starting at fromIndex.

fromIndex.description: Element to locate in the array.The index at

#filter.summary:
Creates a new array with all elements that pass the test implemented by the
provided function.

thisObject.description: Function to test each element of the array.Object to

#forEach.summary: Executes a provided function once per array element.

thisObject.description: Function to execute for each element.Object to use

#every.summary:
Tests whether all elements in the array pass the test implemented by the
provided function.

Function.description: to test for each element.Object to use as

#some.summary:
Tests whether some element in the array passes the test implemented by the
provided function.

thisObject.description: Function to test for each element.Object to use as

#reduce.summary:
Apply a function against an accumulator and each value of the array (from
left-to-right) as to reduce it to a single value.

Function.description: to execute on each value in the

#reduceRight.summary:
Apply a function simultaneously against two values of the array (from
right-to-left) as to reduce it to a single value.

initialValue.description: Function to execute on each value in the

#bind.summary: Adds a function as an event listener.
#bind.code_sample:
# this will call coolEventHandler after
# yourObject.trigger "someCustomEvent" is called.
yourObject.bind "someCustomEvent", coolEventHandler

#or
yourObject.bind "anotherCustomEvent", ->
  doSomething()

callback.description: The function to be called when the specified event is triggered.

#unbind.summary:
Removes a specific event listener, or all event listeners if
no specific listener is given.
#unbind.code_sample:
Another paragraph.

#  removes the handler coolEventHandler from the event
# "someCustomEvent" while leaving the other events intact.
yourObject.unbind "someCustomEvent", coolEventHandler

# removes all handlers attached to "anotherCustomEvent"
yourObject.unbind "anotherCustomEvent"

event.description: The event to remove the listener from.

#trigger.summary: Calls all listeners attached to the specified event.
#trigger.code_sample:
# calls each event handler bound to "someCustomEvent"
yourObject.trigger "someCustomEvent"

parameters.description: Additional parameters to pass to the event listener.

#toString.summary: Returns a string representing the specified Boolean object.

#valueOf.summary: Returns the primitive value of a Boolean object.

#distance.summary:
Distance between two objects. Proxies to Point.distance.
In order for this to work, otherObj must have a
position method.
#distance.code_sample:
player = GameObject
  x: 50
  y: 50
  width: 10
  height: 10

player.include Bounded

enemy = GameObject
  x: 110
  y: 120
  width: 7
  height: 20

player.distance(enemy)
# => 92.19544457292888

returns.description: Distance between the two objects

#position.summary:
The position of this game object. By default it is the top left point.
Redefining the center method will change the relative position.
#position.code_sample:
player = Core
  x: 50
  y: 40

player.include(Bounded)

player.position()
# => {x: 50, y: 40}

returns.description: The position of this object

#collides.summary:
Does a check to see if this object is overlapping
with the bounds passed in.
#collides.code_sample:
player = Core
  x: 4
  y: 6
  width: 20
  height: 20

player.include(Bounded)

player.collides({x: 5, y: 7, width: 20, height: 20})
# => true

returns.description: The position of this object

#collisionBounds.summary:
This returns a modified bounds based on the collision margin.
The area of the bounds is reduced if collision margin is positive
and increased if collision margin is negative.
#collisionBounds.code_sample:
player = Core
  collisionMargin:
    x: -2
    y: -4
  x: 50
  y: 50
  width: 20
  height: 20

player.include(Bounded)

player.collisionBounds()
# => {x: 38, y: 36, height: 28, width: 24}

player.collisionBounds(10, 10)
# => {x: 48, y: 46, height: 28, width: 24}

xOffset.description: the amount to shift the x position

yOffset.description: the amount to shift the y position

returns.description: The collision bounds

#bounds.summary: Returns infomation about the location of the object and its dimensions with optional offsets.
#bounds.code_sample:
player = Core
  x: 3
  y: 6
  width: 2
  height: 2

player.include(Bounded)

player.bounds()
# => {x: 3, y: 6, width: 2, height: 2}

player.bounds(7, 4)
# => {x: 10, y: 10, width: 2, height: 2}

xOffset.description: the amount to shift the x position

yOffset.description: the amount to shift the y position

#centeredBounds.summary:
The centeredBounds method returns infomation about the center
of the object along with the midpoint of the width and height.
#centeredBounds.code_sample:
player = Core
  x: 3
  y: 6
  width: 2
  height: 2

player.include(Bounded)

player.centeredBounds()
# => {x: 4, y: 7, xw: 1, yw: 1}

#center.summary:
The center method returns the {@link Point} that is
the center of the object.
#center.code_sample:
player = Core
  x: 50
  y: 40
  width: 10
  height: 30

player.include(Bounded)

player.center()
# => {x: 30, y: 35}

returns.description: The middle of the calling object

#circle.summary:
Return the circular bounds of the object. The circle is
centered at the midpoint of the object.
#circle.code_sample:
player = Core
  radius: 5
  x: 50
  y: 50
  other: "stuff"

player.include(Bounded)

player.circle()
# => {radius: 5, x: 50, y: 50}

returns.description: An object with a position and a radius

#fadeIn.summary:
A convenient way to set the flash effect instance variables. This provides a shorthand for fading the screen in
from a given color over a specified duration.
#fadeIn.code_sample:
engine.fadeIn()
# => Sets the effect variables to their default state. This will the screen to go from black to transparent over the next 30 frames.

engine.fadeIn('blue', 50)
# => This effect will start off blue and fade to transparent over 50 frames.

#fadeOut.summary:
A convenient way to set the flash effect instance variables. This provides a shorthand for fading
the screen to a given color over a specified duration.
#fadeOut.code_sample:
camera.fadeOut()
# => Sets the effect variables to their default state. This will the screen to fade from ransparent to black over the next 30 frames.

camera.fadeOut('blue', 50)
# => This effect will start off transparent and change to blue over 50 frames.

#flash.summary:
A convenient way to set the flash effect instance variables. Alternatively, you can modify them by hand, but
using Camera#flash is the suggested approach.
#flash.code_sample:
camera.flash()
# => Sets the flash effect variables to their default state. This will cause a white flash that will turn transparent in the next 12 frames.

camera.flash
  color: 'green'
  duration: 30
# => This flash effect will start off green and fade to transparent over 30 frames.

camera.flash
  color: Color(255, 0, 0, 0)
  duration: 20
  targetAlpha: 1
# => This flash effect will start off transparent and move toward red over 20 frames

targetAlpha=0.description: The alpha value to fade to. By default, this is set to 0, which fades the color to transparent.

#clamp.summary: Keep an objects attributes within a given range.
#clamp.code_sample:
# Player's health will be within [0, 100] at the end of every update
player.clamp
  health:
    min: 0
    max: 100

# Score can only be positive
player.clamp
  score:
    min: 0

#clampToBounds.summary: Helper to clamp the x and y properties of the object to be within a given bounds.

bounds.description: The bounds to clamp the object's position within. Defaults to the app size if none given.

.collide.summary: Collision holds many useful class methods for checking geometric overlap of various objects.
.collide.code_sample:
player = engine.add
  class: "Player"
  x: 0
  y: 0
  width: 10
  height: 10

enemy = engine.add

class: "Enemy"
x: 5
y: 5
width: 10
height: 10

enemy2 = engine.add
  class: "Enemy"
  x: -5
  y: -5
  width: 10
  height: 10

Collision.collide(player, enemy, (p, e) -> ...)
# => callback is called once

Collision.collide(player, [enemy, enemy2], (p, e) -> ...)
# => callback is called twice

Collision.collide("Player", "Enemy", (p, e) -> ...)
# => callback is also called twice

groupA.description: An object or set of objects to check collisions with

groupB.description: An object or set of objects to check collisions with

callback.description: The callback to call when an object of groupA collides

detectionMethod.description: An optional detection method to determine when two

.rectangular.summary:
Takes two bounds objects and returns true if they collide (overlap), false otherwise.
Bounds objects have x, y, width and height properties.
.rectangular.code_sample:
player = GameObject
  x: 0
  y: 0
  width: 10
  height: 10

enemy = GameObject
  x: 5
  y: 5
  width: 10
  height: 10

Collision.rectangular(player, enemy)
# => true

Collision.rectangular(player, {x: 50, y: 40, width: 30, height: 30})
# => false

returns.description: true if the rectangles overlap, false otherwise

.circular.summary:
Takes two circle objects and returns true if they collide (overlap), false otherwise.
Circle objects have x, y, and radius.
.circular.code_sample:
player = GameObject
  x: 5
  y: 5
  radius: 10

enemy = GameObject
  x: 10
  y: 10
  radius: 10

farEnemy = GameObject
  x: 500
  y: 500
  radius: 30

Collision.circular(player, enemy)
# => true

Collision.circular(player, farEnemy)
# => false

returns.description: true is the circles overlap, false otherwise

.rayCircle.summary: Detects whether a line intersects a circle.
.rayCircle.code_sample:
circle = engine.add
  class: "circle"
  x: 50
  y: 50
  radius: 10

Collision.rayCircle(Point(0, 0), Point(1, 0), circle)
# => true

returns.description: true if the line intersects the circle, false otherwise

.rayRectangle.summary: Detects whether a line intersects a rectangle.
.rayRectangle.code_sample:
rect = engine.add
  class: "circle"
  x: 50
  y: 50
  width: 20
  height: 20

Collision.rayRectangle(Point(0, 0), Point(1, 0), rect)
# => true

returns.description: true if the line intersects the rectangle, false otherwise

#channels.summary: Returns the rgba color channels in an array.
#channels.code_sample:
transparent =  Color()

transparent.channels()
# => [0, 0, 0, 0]

red = Color("#FF0000")

red.channels()
# => [255, 0, 0, 1]

rgb = Color(200, 34, 2)

rgb.channels()
# => [200, 34, 2, 1]

returns.description: Array of r, g, b, and alpha values of the color

#complement.summary: A copy of the calling color that is its complementary color on the color wheel.
#complement.code_sample:
red = Color(255, 0, 0)



cyan = red.complement()



to see what they look like



for color, index in [red, cyan]
  canvas.drawRect
    color: color
    x: 20 + (60 * index)
    y: 20 + (60 * index)
    width: 60
    height: 60

returns.description: new color that is a copy of the calling color with its hue shifted by 180 degrees on the color wheel

#complement$.summary: Modifies the calling color to make it the complement of its previous value.
#complement$.code_sample:
red = Color(255, 0, 0)

# modifies red in place to make it into cyan
red.complement$()

red.toString()
# => 'rgba(0, 255, 255, 1)'

returns.description: the color hue shifted by 180 degrees on the color wheel. Modifies the existing color.

#copy.code_sample:
color = Color(0, 100, 200)

copy = color.copy()

color == copy
# => false

color.equal(copy)
# => true

returns.description: A new color. A copy of the calling color

#darken.summary: Returns a copy of the calling color darkened by amount (Lightness of the color ranges from 0 to 1).
#darken.code_sample:
green = Color(0, 255, 0)



darkGreen = green.darken(0.3)



to see what they look like



for color, index in [green, darkGreen]
  canvas.drawRect
    color: color
    x: 20 + (60 * index)
    y: 20 + (60 * index)
    width: 60
    height: 60

returns.description: A new color. The lightness value is reduced by `amount` from the original.

#darken$.summary: Modifies the color so that it is darkened by amount (Lightness of the color ranges from 0 to 1).
#darken$.code_sample:
green = Color(0, 255, 0)

# Modifies green to be darkGreen
green.darken$(0.3)

green.toString()
# => 'rgba(0, 102, 0, 1)'

returns.description: the color with the lightness value reduced by `amount`

#desaturate.summary: A copy of the calling color with its saturation reduced by amount.
#desaturate.code_sample:
blue = Color(0, 0, 255)



desaturatedBlue = blue.desaturate(0.4)



to see what they look like



for color, index in [blue, desaturatedBlue]
  canvas.drawRect
    color: color
    x: 20 + (60 * index)
    y: 20 + (60 * index)
    width: 60
    height: 60

amount.description: Amount to reduce color saturation by (between 0 and 1)

returns.description: A copy of the color with the saturation value reduced by `amount`

#desaturate$.summary: The modified color with its saturation reduced by amount.
#desaturate$.code_sample:
blue = Color(0, 0, 255)

# modifies blue to be desaturatedBlue
blue.desaturate$(0.4)

blue.toString()
# => 'rgba(38, 38, 217, 1)'

amount.description: Amount to reduce color saturation by (between 0 and 1)

returns.description: the color with the saturation value reduced by `amount`

#equal.summary: Determine whether two colors are equal. Compares their r, g, b, and alpha values.
#equal.code_sample:
hex = Color('#ffff00')
rgb = Color(255, 255, 0)

hex == rgb
# => false

hex.equal(rgb)
# => true

other.description: the color to compare to the calling color

returns.description: true if the r, g, b, a values of the colors agree, false otherwise

#grayscale.summary: A copy of the calling color converted to grayscale.
#grayscale.code_sample:
yellow = Color(255, 255, 0)



gray = yellow.grayscale()



to see what they look like



for color, index in [yellow, gray]
  canvas.drawRect
    color: color
    x: 20 + (60 * index)
    y: 20 + (60 * index)
    width: 60
    height: 60

returns.description: A copy of the calling color converted to grayscale.

#grayscale$.code_sample:
color = Color(255, 255, 0)

# modifies color into gray
color.grayscale$()

color.toString()
# => 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 1)'

returns.description: The calling color converted to grayscale.

#hue.summary:
A getter / setter for the hue value of the color. Passing no argument returns the
current hue value. Passing a value will set the hue to that value and return the color.
#hue.code_sample:
magenta = Color(255, 0, 255)



magenta.hue()



=> 300



modifies the color to be yellow



magenta.hue(60)



to see what it looks like



canvas.drawRect
  color: magenta
  x: 50
  y: 30
  width: 80
  height: 80

returns.description: returns the color object if you pass a new hue value and returns the hue otherwise

#lightness.summary:
A getter / setter for the lightness value of the color. Passing no argument returns the
current lightness value. Passing a value will set the lightness to that value and return the color.
#lightness.code_sample:
magenta = Color(255, 0, 255)



magenta.lightness()



=> 0.9



modifies magenta in place to be lighter



magenta.lightness(0.75)



to see what it looks like



canvas.drawRect
  color: magenta
  x: 50
  y: 30
  width: 80
  height: 80

returns.description: returns the color object if you pass a new lightness value and returns the lightness otherwise

#shiftHue.summary: A copy of the calling color with its hue shifted by degrees. This differs from the hue setter in that it adds to the existing hue value and will wrap around 0 and 360.
#shiftHue.code_sample:
magenta = Color(255, 0, 255)



magenta.hue()



=> 300



yellow = magenta.shiftHue(120)



since magenta's hue is 300 we have wrapped



around 360 to end up at 60



yellow.hue()



=> 60



to see what they look like



for color, index in [magenta, yellow]
  canvas.drawRect
    color: color
    x: 20 + (60 * index)
    y: 20 + (60 * index)
    width: 60
    height: 60

degrees.description: number of degrees to shift the hue on the color wheel.

returns.description: A copy of the color with its hue shifted by `degrees`

#shiftHue$.summary: The calling color with its hue shifted by degrees. This differs from the hue setter in that it adds to the existing hue value and will wrap around 0 and 360.
#shiftHue$.code_sample:
magenta = Color(255, 0, 255)

magenta.hue()
# => 300

magenta.shiftHue$(120)

# since magenta's hue is 300 we have wrapped
# around 360 to end up at 60. Also we have
# modified magenta in place to become yellow
magenta.hue()
# => 60

magenta.toString()
# => 'rgba(255, 255, 0, 1)'

degrees.description: number of degrees to shift the hue on the color wheel.

returns.description: The color with its hue shifted by `degrees`

#lighten.summary: Returns a copy of the calling color lightened by amount (Lightness of the color ranges from 0 to 1).
#lighten.code_sample:
green = Color(0, 255, 0)



lightGreen = green.lighten(0.3)



to see what they look like



for color, index in [green, lightGreen]
  canvas.drawRect
    color: color
    x: 20 + (60 * index)
    y: 20 + (60 * index)
    width: 60
    height: 60

amount.description: Amount to lighten color by (between 0 to 1)

returns.description: A new color. The lightness value is increased by `amount` from the original.

#lighten$.summary: The calling color lightened by amount (Lightness of the color ranges from 0 to 1).
#lighten$.code_sample:
green = Color(0, 255, 0)

green.lighten$(0.2)

# we have modified green in place
# to become lightGreen
green.toString()

=> 'rgba(102, 255, 102, 1)'

returns.description: The calling color with its lightness value increased by `amount`.

#mixWith.summary:
A copy of the calling color mixed with other using amount as the
mixing ratio. If amount is not passed, then the colors are mixed evenly.
#mixWith.code_sample:
red = Color(255, 0, 0)
yellow = Color(255, 255, 0)



With no amount argument the colors are mixed evenly



orange = red.mixWith(yellow)



With an amount of 0.3 we are mixing the color 30% red and 70% yellow



somethingCloseToOrange = red.mixWith(yellow, 0.3)



to see what they look like



for color, index in [red, yellow, orange, somethingCloseToOrange]
  canvas.drawRect
    color: color
    x: 20 + (60 * (index % 2))
    y: 20 + (60 * (if index > 1 then 1 else 0))
    width: 60
    height: 60

amount.description: the mixing ratio of the calling color to `other`

returns.description: A new color that is a mix of the calling color and `other`

#mixWith$.summary:
A copy of the calling color mixed with other using amount as the
mixing ratio. If amount is not passed, then the colors are mixed evenly.
#mixWith$.code_sample:
red = Color(255, 0, 0)
yellow = Color(255, 255, 0)
anotherRed = Color(255, 0, 0)

# With no amount argument the colors are mixed evenly
red.mixWith$(yellow)

# We have modified red in place to be orange
red.toString()
# => 'rgba(255, 128, 0, 1)'

# With an amount of 0.3 we are mixing the color 30% red and 70% yellow
anotherRed.mixWith$(yellow, 0.3)

# We have modified `anotherRed` in place to be somethingCloseToOrange
anotherRed.toString()
# => rgba(255, 179, 0, 1)

amount.description: the mixing ratio of the calling color to `other`

returns.description: The modified calling color after mixing it with `other`

#saturate.summary: A copy of the calling color with its saturation increased by amount.

for color, index in [color, saturatedColor]

    height: 60

amount.description: the amount to increase saturation by

#saturate$.summary: The calling color with its saturation increased by amount.

.mix.summary: Mix two colors. Behaves just like #mixWith except that you are passing two colors.
.mix.code_sample:
red = Color(255, 0, 0)
yellow = Color(255, 255, 0)

# With no amount argument the colors are mixed evenly
orange = Color.mix(red, yellow)

orange.toString()
# => 'rgba(255, 128, 0, 1)'

# With an amount of 0.3 we are mixing the color 30% red and 70% yellow
somethingCloseToOrange = Color.mix(red, yellow, 0.3)

somethingCloseToOrange.toString()
# => rgba(255, 179, 0, 1)

amount.description: the ratio to mix the colors

returns.description: A new color that is the two colors mixed at the ratio defined by `amount`

#attrAccessor.summary:
Generates a public jQuery style getter / setter method for each
String argument.
#attrAccessor.code_sample:
myObject = Core
  r: 255
  g: 0
  b: 100

myObject.attrAccessor "r", "g", "b"

myObject.r(254)
myObject.r()

=> 254

#attrReader.summary: Generates a public jQuery style getter method for each String argument.
#attrReader.code_sample:
myObject = Core
  r: 255
  g: 0
  b: 100

myObject.attrReader "r", "g", "b"

myObject.r()
=> 255

myObject.g()
=> 0

myObject.b()
=> 100

#extend.summary: Extends this object with methods from the passed in object. A shortcut for Object.extend(self, methods)
#extend.code_sample:
I =
  x: 30
  y: 40
  maxSpeed: 5

# we are using extend to give player
# additional methods that Core doesn't have
player = Core(I).extend
  increaseSpeed: ->
    I.maxSpeed += 1

player.I.maxSpeed
=> 5

player.increaseSpeed()

player.I.maxSpeed
=> 6

#include.code_sample:
myObject = Core()
myObject.include(Bindable)

# now you can bind handlers to functions
myObject.bind "someEvent", ->
  alert("wow. that was easy.")

Module.description: the module to include. A module is a constructor that takes two parameters, I and self, and returns an object containing the public methods to extend the including object with.

#debug.summary: Enable debugging display for the calling GameObject.
#debug.code_sample:
player = GameObject
  x: 40
  y: 14
  spriteName: null
  numericErrorProperty: NaN

player.include Debuggable

# sets up debug output for all player's properties
# at the starting position (0, 0)
player.debug
  filter: 'all'

player.I.y = 45

# sets up debug output for only properties that have
# changed since initialization. In this case only y
# would be displayed.
player.debug
  filter: 'changed'

# sets up debug output for properties that are <code>undefined</code>,
# <code>null</code>, or <code>NaN</code>. In this case spriteName and
# numericErrorProperty would be displayed.
player.debug
  filter: 'undefined'

# sets up debug output using all possible configuration options
player.debug
  bounds: true # set this to false to disable visual debugging of the object's bounding box
  color: 'red' # color of debug text
  filter: 'all'
  x: 30 # x position to start printing debug information
  y: 50 # y position to start printing debug information
  velocity: true # set this to false to disable visual debugging of the object's velocity

bounds.description: Whether or not to visually debug the object's bounds

color.description: The color of the debug text

x.description: The x position to start drawing the debug information

y.description: The y position to start drawing the debug information

velocity.description: Whether or not to visually debug the object's velocity

#toggleDebug.code_sample:
player = GameObject()

player.include Debuggable

# enables debug display
player.debug()

# disables debug display
player.toggleDisable()

# if false is passed to toggleDisplay, then debugging is disabled.
player.toggleDisplay(false)

# if true is passed to toggleDisplay, then debugging is enabled.
player.toggleDisplay(true)

newVal.description: If true is passed then debugging is enabled, if false is passed then debugging is disabled, if nothing is passed, then debug state is toggled.

#draw.summary:
Draw does not actually do any drawing itself, instead it triggers all of the draw events.
Listeners on the events do the actual drawing.

#beforeTransform.summary:
Triggered before the object should be drawn. A canvas is passed as
the first argument. This does not apply the current transform.

canvas.description: A reference to the canvas to draw on.

#afterTransform.summary:
Triggered after the object should be drawn. A canvas is passed as
the first argument. This applies the current transform.

canvas.description: A reference to the canvas to draw on.

#transform.summary: Returns the current transform, with translation, rotation, and flipping applied.

returns.description: The current transform

#beforeAdd.summary:
Observe or modify the
entity data before it is added to the engine.

#afterAdd.summary:
Observe or configure a gameObject that has been added
to the engine.

object.description: The object that has just been added to the

#update.summary: Called when the engine updates all the game objects.

#afterUpdate.summary:
Called after the engine completes an update. Here it is
safe to modify the game objects array.

#beforeDraw.summary: Called before the engine draws the game objects on the canvas. The current camera transform is applied.

#draw.summary: Called after the engine draws on the canvas. The current camera transform is applied.
#draw.code_sample:
engine.bind "draw", (canvas) ->
  # print some directions for the player
  canvas.drawText
    text: "Go this way =>"
    x: 200
    y: 200

#overlay.code_sample:
The current camera transform is not applied. This is great for
adding overlays.

engine.bind "overlay", (canvas) ->
  # print the player's health. This will be
  # positioned absolutely according to the viewport.
  canvas.drawText
    text: "HEALTH:"
    position: Point(20, 20)

  canvas.drawText
    text: player.health()
    position: Point(50, 20)

#find.summary:
Get a selection of GameObjects that match the specified selector criteria. The selector language
can select objects by id, class, or attributes. Note that this method always returns an Array,
so if you are trying to find only one object you will need something like engine.find("Enemy").first()
#find.code_sample:
player = engine.add
  class: "Player"

enemy = engine.add
  class: "Enemy"
  speed: 5
  x: 0

distantEnemy = engine.add
  class "Enemy"
  x: 500

boss = engine.add
  class: "Enemy"
  id: "Boss"
  x: 0

# to select an object by id use "#anId"
engine.find "#Boss"
# => [boss]

# to select an object by class use "MyClass"
engine.find "Enemy"
# => [enemy, distantEnemy, boss]

# to select an object by properties use ".someProperty" or ".someProperty=someValue"
engine.find ".speed=5"
# => [enemy]

# You may mix and match selectors.
engine.find "Enemy.x=0"
# => [enemy, boss] # doesn't return distantEnemy

returns.description: An array of the objects found

#loadMap.summary: Loads a new may and unloads any existing map or entities.

#add.summary:
The add method creates and adds an object to the game world. Two
other events are triggered around this one: beforeAdd and afterAdd.
#add.code_sample:
# you can add arbitrary entityData and
# the engine will make it into a GameObject
engine.add
  x: 50
  y: 30
  color: "red"

player = engine.add
  class: "Player"

entityData.description: The data used to create the game object.

#controller.summary: Get a controller for a given joystick id.

i.description: The joystick id to get the controller of.

#fadeOut.summary:
A convenient way to set the fade instance variables on a sprite. You can modify the
instance variables by hand but the suggested way to do it is through this method.
#fadeOut.code_sample:
player = GameObject()

player.include(Fadeable)

fadedOut = false

# this will fade the player object out over the next 30 frames.
# once the player is faded out the fadedOut variable will be set to true.
player.fadeOut 30, (player) ->
  fadedOut = true

30.times ->
  player.update()

fadedOut
# => true

callback=null.description: The function to execute when the sprite has finished fading.

#flicker.summary:
A convenient way to set the flicker instance variables on a sprite. You can modify the
instance variables by hand but the suggested way to do it is through this method.
#flicker.code_sample:
player = GameObject()

player.include(Flickerable)

player.flicker()
# => This causes the sprite to flicker between full opacity
# => and 50% opacity every 3 frames for 30 frames

player.flicker(90, 5, 0.3)
# => This causes the sprite to flicker between full opacity
# => and 30% opacity every 5 frames for 90 frames

frequency=3.description: The number of frames in between opacity changes

alpha=0.5.description: The alpha value to flicker to

#debounce.summary:
Calling a debounced function will postpone its execution until after
wait milliseconds have elapsed since the last time the function was
invoked. Useful for implementing behavior that should only happen after
the input has stopped arriving. For example: rendering a preview of a
Markdown comment, recalculating a layout after the window has stopped
being resized...

returns.description: The debounced version of this function.

Creates a new function that, when called, itself calls this function in the
context of the provided this value, with a given sequence of arguments preceding
any provided when the new function was called.

arg2,.description: ... The value to be passed as the this parameter to

#call.summary: Calls a function with a given this value and arguments provided individually.

Determines.description: the value of this inside fun. If thisArg is null or

#toString.summary: Returns a string representing the source code of the function.

Non-standard.description: The amount of spaces to indent the string

#create.summary: Triggers the create event if the object has not already been created.

#destroy.summary: Destroys the object and triggers the destroyed event.

#step.code_sample:
player = GameObject()

player.bind 'step', ->
  # check to see if keys are being pressed and
  # change the player's velocity
  if keydown.left
    player.velocity(Point(-1, 0))
  else if keydown.right
    player.velocity(Point(1, 0))
  else
    player.velocity(Point(0, 0))

Triggered when the object is removed from

#overlay.summary: Draws Game Over screen and reset instructions.

#saveState.summary: Save the current game state and returns a JSON object representing that state.

returns.description: An array of the instance data of all objects in the game state

#loadState.summary: Loads the game state passed in, or the last saved state, if any.
#loadState.code_sample:
engine.bind 'update', ->
  if justPressed.l
    # loads the last saved state
    engine.loadState()

  if justPressed.o
    # removes all game objects, then reinstantiates
    # them with the entityData passed in
    engine.loadState([{x: 40, y: 50, class: "Player"}, {x: 0, y: 0, class: "Enemy"}, {x: 500, y: 400, class: "Boss"}])

An.description: arraf of object instance data to load.

#reload.summary: Reloads the current game state, useful for hotswapping code.
#reload.code_sample:
engine.I.objects.each (object) ->
  # bring all objects to (0, 0) for some reason
  object.I.x = 0
  object.I.y = 0

# reload all objects to make sure
# they are at (0, 0)
engine.reload()

.uuid.code_sample:
// No arguments  - returns RFC4122, version 4 ID
  Math.uuid()
=> "92329D39-6F5C-4520-ABFC-AAB64544E172"



// One argument - returns ID of the specified length
  Math.uuid(15)     // 15 character ID (default base=62)
=> "VcydxgltxrVZSTV"



// Two arguments - returns ID of the specified length, and radix. (Radix must be <= 62)
  Math.uuid(8, 2)  // 8 character ID (base=2)
=> "01001010"



Math.uuid(8, 10) // 8 character ID (base=10)
=> "47473046"



Math.uuid(8, 16) // 8 character ID (base=16)
=> "098F4D35"

The.description: number of allowable values for each character.

#concat.summary:
Returns the result of this matrix multiplied by another matrix
combining the geometric effects of the two. In mathematical terms,
concatenating two matrixes is the same as combining them using matrix multiplication.
If this matrix is A and the matrix passed in is B, the resulting matrix is A x B
http://mathworld.wolfram.com/MatrixMultiplication.html

matrix.description: The matrix to multiply this matrix by.

returns.description: The result of the matrix multiplication, a new matrix.
A copy of this matrix.

#deltaTransformPoint.summary:
Given a point in the pretransform coordinate space, returns the coordinates of
that point after the transformation occurs. Unlike the standard transformation
applied using the transformPoint() method, the deltaTransformPoint() method
does not consider the translation parameters tx and ty.

returns.description: A new matrix that is the inverse of this matrix.

#rotate.summary:
Returns a new matrix that corresponds this matrix multiplied by a
a rotation matrix.

aboutPoint.description: The point about which this rotation occurs. Defaults to (0,0).

returns.description: A new matrix, rotated by the specified amount.

#scale.summary:
Returns a new matrix that corresponds this matrix multiplied by a
a scaling matrix.

aboutPoint.description: The point that remains fixed during the scaling

returns.description: A new Matrix. The original multiplied by a scaling matrix.

#toString.summary: Returns a string representation of this matrix.

returns.description: A string reperesentation of this matrix.

#transformPoint.summary:
Returns the result of applying the geometric transformation represented by the
Matrix object to the specified point.

returns.description: A new point with the transformation applied.

#translate.summary: Translates the matrix along the x and y axes, as specified by the tx and ty parameters.

tx.description: The translation along the x axis.

ty.description: The translation along the y axis.

returns.description: A new matrix with the translation applied.

#meter.summary: Configures a meter to be drawn each overlay event.
#meter.code_sample:
player = GameObject

player.include Metered

player.meter 'health',
  border
    color: 'brown'
    radius: 3
  color: 'pink'
  height: 20
  x: 5
  y: 5
  show: true
  width: 150

# => Sets up a health meter, using all the configuration options

name.description: The name of the property to meter

border:.description: radius Border radius of the meter

color.description: Color of the meter's inner rectangle

position.description: An x, y object representing the position of the meter

show.description: Boolean to toggle whether of not to display the meter

#showMeter.code_sample:
player = GameObject

player.include Metered

# creates a health meter but disables visibility
player.meter 'health'
  show: false

# enables visibility for the meter named 'health'
player.showMeter 'health'

name.description: The name of the meter to show

#hideMeter.code_sample:
player = GameObject

player.include Metered

# creates a health meter
player.meter 'health'

.reverseMerge.summary:
Merges properties from objects into target without overiding.
First come, first served.
.reverseMerge.code_sample:
I =
  a: 1
  b: 2
  c: 3

Object.reverseMerge I,
  c: 6
  d: 4

I # => {a: 1, b:2, c:3, d: 4}

target.description: The object to merge the properties into.

returns.description: target

.extend.summary:
Merges properties from sources into target with overiding.
Last in covers earlier properties.
.extend.code_sample:
I =
  a: 1
  b: 2
  c: 3

Object.extend I,
  c: 6
  d: 4

I # => {a: 1, b:2, c:6, d: 4}

target.description: The object to merge the properties into.

returns.description: target

#add.summary:
Adds a point to this one and returns the new point. You may
also use a two argument call like point.add(x, y)
to add x and y values without a second point object.
#add.code_sample:
point = Point(2, 3).add(Point(3, 4))

point.x
# => 5

point.y
# => 7

anotherPoint = Point(2, 3).add(3, 4)

anotherPoint.x
# => 5

anotherPoint.y
# => 7

other.description: The point to add this point to.

returns.description: A new point, the sum of both.

#add$.summary:
Adds a point to this one, returning a modified point. You may
also use a two argument call like point.add(x, y)
to add x and y values without a second point object.
#add$.code_sample:
point = Point(2, 3)

point.x
# => 2

point.y
# => 3

point.add$(Point(3, 4))

point.x
# => 5

point.y
# => 7

anotherPoint = Point(2, 3)
anotherPoint.add$(3, 4)

anotherPoint.x
# => 5

anotherPoint.y
# => 7

other.description: The point to add this point to.

returns.description: The sum of both points.

#subtract.summary: Subtracts a point to this one and returns the new point.
#subtract.code_sample:
point = Point(1, 2).subtract(Point(2, 0))

point.x
# => -1

point.y
# => 2

anotherPoint = Point(1, 2).subtract(2, 0)

anotherPoint.x
# => -1

anotherPoint.y
# => 2

other.description: The point to subtract from this point.

returns.description: A new point, this - other.

#subtract$.summary: Subtracts a point to this one and returns the new point.
#subtract$.code_sample:
point = Point(1, 2)

point.x
# => 1

point.y
# => 2

point.subtract$(Point(2, 0))

point.x
# => -1

point.y
# => 2

anotherPoint = Point(1, 2)
anotherPoint.subtract$(2, 0)

anotherPoint.x
# => -1

anotherPoint.y
# => 2

other.description: The point to subtract from this point.

returns.description: The difference of the two points.

#scale$.summary: Scale this Point (Vector) by a constant amount. Modifies the point in place.

point.x
# => 5

point.y
# => 6

point.scale$(2)

point.x
# => 10

point.y
# => 12

scalar.description: The amount to scale this point by.

#norm.summary:
The norm of a vector is the unit vector pointing in the same direction. This method
treats the point as though it is a vector from the origin to (x, y).
#norm.code_sample:
point = Point(2, 3).norm()

point.x
# => 0.5547001962252291

point.y
# => 0.8320502943378437

anotherPoint = Point(2, 3).norm(2)

anotherPoint.x
# => 1.1094003924504583

anotherPoint.y
# => 1.6641005886756874

returns.description: The unit vector pointing in the same direction as this vector.

#norm$.summary:
The norm of a vector is the unit vector pointing in the same direction. This method
treats the point as though it is a vector from the origin to (x, y). Modifies the point in place.
#norm$.code_sample:
point = Point(2, 3).norm$()

point.x
# => 0.5547001962252291

point.y
# => 0.8320502943378437

anotherPoint = Point(2, 3).norm$(2)

anotherPoint.x
# => 1.1094003924504583

anotherPoint.y
# => 1.6641005886756874

returns.description: The unit vector pointing in the same direction as this vector.

#cross.summary:
Calculate the cross product of this point and another point (Vector).
Usually cross products are thought of as only applying to three dimensional vectors,
but z can be treated as zero. The result of this method is interpreted as the magnitude
of the vector result of the cross product between [x1, y1, 0] x [x2, y2, 0]
perpendicular to the xy plane.
